results.title: Holding on to what is real
results.creator_credit: Karin Altmann, Tassos Ioannides, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service, Australia. Dept. of Health, Housing and Community Services and Kitaron
results.brief_description: Samantha is a young Victorian woman suffering from schizophrenia and the stigma associated with the condition. Her courage and determination to emerge from the dark tunnel of her illness is apparent by the way she discusses her experiences. Schizophrenia affects 27% of Australian families and Samantha’s revealing and honest story does much to dispel the many misconceptions society has about the illness and is a testimony to her extraordinary strength and courage.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Karin Altmann, Tassos Ioannides, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service, Australia. Dept. of Health, Housing and Community Services and Kitaron

results.title: Hold: Vessel #1 and Vessel #2
results.material_description: video, projection, glass, colour and sound
results.brief_description:
Hold: Vessel 1 is a magical interactive experience in which visitors to the gallery try to catch a mesmerizing series of projected visions in a delicate glass bowl - echoing the wondrous views of the world made possible with the first microscopes, underwater cameras and astronomical cinematography.
Lynette Wallworth began her career in photography, and has also worked in short film, installation and performance. She creates installation spaces that require activation by the participant/viewer. To collect the images used in Hold: Vessel 1 she collaborated with scientific image libraries and specialist cinematographers, as part of her ongoing investigation into imaging technologies that enable us to see the world in ways otherwise inaccessible to the naked human eye. Hold: Vessel 1 consists of video projections with directional sound scape beamed from above into a darkened space. The visitor is invited to take hold of a glass bowl and catch the images within it, finding the point at which the vision is most clear and resolved. A personal portal opens to us as we cradle the bowl in our hands. Imagery in ‘Hold’ is derived mainly from Australian scientists and specialist cinematographers including: David Hannan, who has adapted medical imaging technology to film extreme macro images of the Great Barrier Reef, Anya Salih, who investigates coral fluorescence and Greg Rouse, Marine Biologist. The work is designed as a vessel to hold a changing pool of imagery. Hold: Vessel 1 will change in time as time changes the environments it reflects.

results.title: Hold up!!
results.creator_credit: Gaylene Preston, Dave Gibson and Gibson Film Productions
results.brief_description: The film presents a drama in which three disabled people are key witnesses to a robbery but have trouble breaking through the crowd to tell the police. Following the drama the three main actors, who are themselves disabled, share some of their real life experiences and explain how they deal with prejudice. Recommended for 8-14 year olds
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gaylene Preston, Dave Gibson and Gibson Film Productions

results.title: Hold the land
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Collings, Geoffrey Bell and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: In the past, soil erosion has been a contributing factor in the decline of former civilizations. With this in mind, the film stresses the seriousness of the soil erosion problem in Australia. Wind and water have taken a heavy toll of the soil. The measures being taken to control erosion are illustrated and it is stressed that both the man on the land and also the city dweller must learn to work with nature in preserving the heritage of the living soil.

results.title: Hold the ketchup
results.creator_credit: Albert Kish, William Weintraub and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This is about new Canadians and what they eat. Funny, mouth-watering and visually delectable, it takes us into the specialty food shops where the ingredients are bought, and into the homes where the food is prepared and served in the traditional way.

results.brief_description: The cowboy on the ranch; farming cattle, collecting bison and also wild horses, rodeo where the cowboys ride wild horses. Narrated by Ford Bond.

results.title: Hokusai: an animated sketch book
results.creator_credit: Tony White and Arts Council of Great Britain
results.brief_description: An animated tribute to an “old man mad about drawing”, Japanese artist, Katsushika Hokusai, 1760-1849, which explores 60 of the 30 thousand drawings he is reputed to have produced during his lifetime. Narrated by Michael Bates. Voice of Hokusai: Eric Chitty.

results.title: Hokusai: 'Thirty-six views of Mount Fuji'
results.brief_description: The narration in the film gives detailed information on the life and work of Hokusai. The film explores his “Thirty-six Views of Mt Fuji” and his art showing the life of the common man. Also outlines the history of modern Japanese art. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Hog family 'supreme'
results.creator_credit: Larry Gosnell, Lawrence Cherry, Evelyn Cherry and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: More than fifty percent of Prince Edward Island’s hog production is classified Grade A. From a plan for live-hog grading we see how further standards were devised, culminating in the superior quality that makes Island breeding stock popular around the world.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Larry Gosnell, Lawrence Cherry, Evelyn Cherry and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Hoffnung's birds bees and storks
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Tales from Hoffnung”.
A cautionary tale told by a father to his teenage son. He is revealing with great embarrassment to himself, the facts of life. However it seems the father is without knowledge himself, and at the end has managed to say very little. Based on the cartoon drawings of Gerard Hoffnung. Narrated by Peter Sellars with animation by Tony Guy.
